tell.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if someone tells you something, they communicate information, a story, their feelings etc to you
tell.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She told us some funny stories about her sister.
Tell me straight, Adam. Just answer yes or no.
I wish someone had told me the meeting was canceled.
The Chief of Police told reporters that two people were killed in the blast.
Jack had to go, but he didn’t tell me why.
I think you’d better tell me exactly what’s been going on around here.
No one had told them about the drug’s side effects.
I’ll tell you all about it when I get back.
Tell me your phone number again.
tell.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: In written English, people often prefer to say that another writer describes something, rather than using tell:
His book describes how the human brain has developed.
tell.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to give information in ways other than talking
tell.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The light tells you when the machine is ready.
The bear’s sense of smell tells it where prey is hiding.
What do these fossils tell us about climate change?
tell.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to say that someone must do something
tell.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Do as you are told (=obey me) and don’t ask questions.
The teacher told the children to sit down quietly.
I thought I told you not to touch anything!
Bernice was told she had to work late this evening.
Stop trying to tell me what to do all the time.
tell.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to know something or be able to recognize something because of certain signs that show this
tell.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: You could tell a mile off that he was lying.
She might have been lying. Benjy couldn’t tell.
The moment Kramer walked in, I could tell that things were not going well.
It’s hard to tell how long the job will take.
I could tell from his tone of voice that Ken was disappointed.
tell.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to be able to see how one person or thing is different from another
tell.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Can you tell the difference between sparkling wine and champagne?
How can you tell a fake Vuitton handbag from the real thing?
tell.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to warn someone that something bad might happen
tell.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I told you it was a waste of time talking to him.
My mother told me not to trust Robert.
tell.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to tell someone in authority about something wrong that someone you know has done – used especially by children
tell.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: If you hit me, I’ll tell.
tell.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to have an effect on someone, especially a harmful one
tell.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: These late nights are really beginning to tell on him.
tell.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: He then told the story of how he was injured while riding his motorcycle.
They sat around telling terrible jokes.
I offered to tell her my secret if she didn’t tell anyone else.
‘I’m telling you the truth, ’ she persisted.
tell.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with tell
tell.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0]: In meaning 1, tell is transitive and must be followed by an object
tell.translation[0].note_box[1].items[2]: He told the news to his mother
He told to his mother the news
tell.translation[0].note_box[1].items[3]: He told me about his feelings
tell.translation[0].note_box[1].items[4]: You tell someone to do something
He told me to sit down
tell.translation[0].note_box[1].items[5]: You use tell someone (that) when reporting what someone said
He told them that he was sorry
She told me I could go
He told that he was sorry
tell.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: to give someone information by speaking or writing to them
She wrote to tell me she was getting married.
Can you tell us where the nearest garage is?
let somebody know
to tell someone something when you know more about it
Let me know your new address as soon as you can.
Let us know what happens at the interview.
pass a message on to somebody
to tell another person the information that has been told to you
She’s with a client at the moment, but I’ll pass the message on to her.
If I get any news, I’ll pass it on.
to give someone all the necessary information about a situation, so that they can do their work
Police officers were briefed before going out to arrest the suspects.
relate
to tell someone about something that happened to you or to someone else
One girl related a story about a friend who had accidentally become pregnant.
recount
to tell someone about a series of events
The guide recounted the history of the castle, from the 1300s onwards.
bring something to somebody’s attention
to tell someone about something that they did not know about, but which they need to know about
I wanted to bring the matter to your attention.
She was the first person to study the effects of pesticides, and to bring them to people’s attention.
fill somebody in
to tell someone about things that have happened recently, especially at work
Can you fill Robert in on the progress we’ve made while he’s been on holiday?
to officially tell someone
inform
to officially tell someone about something
Do you think we ought to inform the police?
Doctors should inform patients about the possible side effects of any drugs they prescribe.
announce
to tell people publicly and officially about something
The university chancellor announced his resignation on Friday.
It was announced that the company had made a profit of $6 billion.
report
to officially tell someone about something that has happened
She was able to report that the project was nearly finished.
notify
to tell someone officially about something that has happened or that is planned to happen
Staff were notified several months in advance that they would be losing their jobs.
